40965045.review:
Singularity seems to be from a time when even big publishers like Ubisoft still sponsored interesting FPS games. The only real problem the game has is that it's way too short. You can complete it in about 5 to 6 hours easily, faster if you just rush through of course. That being said, if the game were longer it would overstay its welcome since there's only so much you can do with what you have. This is no Half Life, it's not Bioshock, the story is mediocre and predictable, but somewhat entertaining. The graphics are nice and the weapons are rather standard but with a little twist. The upgrade system in the game is straight forward as well, so nothing special, nothing interesting, just "stats" upgrades really and they're the same for each weapon.

What makes Singularity so interesting, however, is its world design. While the levels are strictly linear with only a few branching sections to explore and find items, each zone feels adequately different, ranging from research stations to derelict shipyards to underground mazes. They've poured enough soul and effort into the level design that it's just fun to play through. The gunplay and the few puzzles are also quite good for the most part. And the biggest selling point is of course the TMD, the time manipulation device, which lets you change the time state of many objects and enemies in the game, opening up a lot of possibilities. Thanks to the enemy variety there's almost always something new to shoot, so you don't get overly bored. The only gripe I'd have here is that they've definitely opted for quantity over quality, but oh well. Another thing that sets this one apart is that for once it's not about the Americans (despite you playing one), it's about Russia and its people.

In the levels you'll find notes and audio logs to listen to just like in Bioshock for example, which add to the atmosphere. Sound design and the time echoes you'll experience as well as switching from the present to the past all add to the feeling of actually playing in a fleshed out world, instead of just a set of random levels stringed together. Too bad the characters, especially the big bad, are extremely shallow and lack character, but nothing is perfect. For 20 bucks I'd recommend this one. If it's on sale even more. It's one of those shooters that has stood the test of time rather well and is still fun to play, even if it is rather short.

40473147.review:
FPS set in Russia. Something is weird on an island that should be uninhabited. The U.S. illegally sends a team in to investigate. They get shot down and now you're running around trying to figure out the mystery this island holds. Turns out the Russians built a base there 50 years ago, but if it was abandoned, what is happening there right now?

This is not a triple A title, so that might explain the $30 tag and the not triple A graphics. They don't suck by any means, but they're not cutting edge either. This isn't Crysis. I guess it came out in 2010, so...I guess the graphics fit. 

I played on normal difficulty and really didn't have much trouble. I died here and there, but I only ever hit one moment that seemed difficult until I remembered a game mechanic I was supposed to be using. 

Weapons are standard for FPS games. Pistol, machine gun, shotgun, minigun, rocket launcher, grenade launcher, sniper rifle, spikegun (sniper rifle with guideable bullets), and I think that's it? There are some other special ones for certain moments. You can only carry two guns at a time except when you get a special weapon. I used the pistol initially, then the shotgun, then the machine gun/minigun exclusively. Use burst fire and ammo will never be a problem. I found no need to carry anything else. There's one area that might be good for the sniper rifle and its ilk, otherwise you're indoors and in tight spaces. The grenade launcher I used for a single shot IMMEDIATELY upon finding it (that's a hint...) and then never needed it again. I don't think I ever needed the rocket launcher. 

You also have a TMD that is like a glove that controls time and gives you some powers. The whole game revolves around it, but I didn't need it much at all except when the plot told me to use it. There is one enemy that using it on makes your life easier, but other than them (another hint) you can just run and gun. 

The story is solid enough to drive you forward, but there are logic holes you could fly a Chinook through. There are also three endings that I found. Finding two of them is obvious, the last one (actually the first one I found) might not be so obvious...but it is... (It's also the best, imho.) Pretty short though. I have 18.3 hours listed on my Steam account for it, and a LOT of that time is the game sitting while I'm watching a movie, eating, working on other things, etc.

Overall, a fun game. I wouldn't recommend it at the $30 price tag it current has in the store, but at $10 it's a good buy for FPS fans.

40468734.review:
One of the best cliche "time-manipulation" FPS in a history.
Truly! Nothing extraordinary, but also nothing bad either.
Enjoy the classic story where some "evil" scientist found a way how to manipulate with time. Of course... something bad happened and You must fix it. Fight the evil forces, fight the "time-mutated" monsters.

One can say: "Nothing special..."

But there few thing which makes this old FPS still good.
- time manipulation device (kill your enemies using time - make them too old XD)
- use time to destroy obstacles, make flora grow, create anomalies, and more
- interesting monsters who can be altered by using time device
- some good weapons (rifle with homing bullets, bullet time sniper rifle, grenade launcher with remote controlled grenades)
- special abilities (something like a passive plasmids in Bioshock)
- STORY! Big plus! Cliche... but still pretty good and... THERE ARE MORE THAN 3 ENDINGS : )

So... if YOu missed this game, try it! It is still very good one!

40331206.review:
I'll get the bad side out of the way: This game is shoooort. Barelly seven hours to finish the campain, maybe a little more if you really try to get every items hidden in the level. Plus, and I think it's a problem with the adaptation with the PC version, the voices are really low compared to the music and other sounds, especially when you try to listen to radio logs.

But now, let's talk about the great stuff. At first, it look like a classic FPS with a gimmic, but as soon as you get the TMD, the game take another dimension. It still mostly a shooter, but there is many situations where it's useful to learn to use your powers. Some might say it's a bad thing, but I like that it take about an hour before getting any real powers to add to the shooter side of things. It allow a build-up that doesn't make you feel like it's forced.

The plot is very interesting, original even, even though it's not mind-blowing. There is a diversity in the level, and once you get the TMD, a few puzzles are throwed your way to make you think a little (don't worry, it's not Portal level of brain bleeding XD). There is, however, like Portal, sometime where you have to think in "4D", as you have the power to change how the environnement react to the situation to solve enigma.

Good diversity of enemies also, divided between humans soldiers and mutants, both sides having many sub-categories.

I also like that, even though it's a shooter, you have a chance to get upgrades on your weapons, tools and yourself, and properly "level up".

As for the graphics, well for an almost ten years old game, it's more than decent. Good visual, interesting enemy designs, decors not too blocky. You won't be sick with pixels the size of your fist.

So, even though it's not the greatest game around, it's definetly a good game worth buying during a sale, if you have a day or two to kill. I just regret that it was so short, but maybe it's for the best, for it would have had the risk to became boring.

39895307.review:
The game has an interesting story, has creative design and solid gameplay, it has so much potential to be a very good game, but it lacks polish, it looks like an unfinished piece to me.

I like the game pretty much actually, the TMD and the guns are fun, love that Kasimov SNV-E99 Sniper Rifle. And the machinery design is just amazing, remember the TMD upgrading process? 
Also the story... I took some time to clear the timelines after finishing the game, and found out that the there're some major paradoxes, I always like paradox settings. 

I can see singularity had borrowed a lot from Bioshock, but I don't think the story was told in a good way like Bioshock. The characters are just stereotype, they come and go and talk, just to get me moving in the game. There's just one villain has a name. If you break down the story and see it for yourself, you'll realize it's something big. I hope i can say this is a great story, but it's just an interesting one.



Other Cons!
The save system really sucks!!!!!!!!!! Especially in the first 1/3 of the game, some people would probably quit due to this, Autosave is understandable, lots of games use autosave. But singularity just saves in wrong places all the time!!! It's like the checkpoints are just placed there without much consideration. 

E-99 money, story notes, records, upgrade systems, they all pops up now and then to "invite" you to interact with them. But lots of those moments, while I was interacting with them, then the combat started, so I had to quit reading/upgrading, because there wasn't a pause in game when you're reading/upgrading.

The puzzles are made for the TMD, so that you can use the TMD. 

All in all, I still finished the game, some moments were enjoyable, the story kept me thinking after the ending, so I would say this is a good game, a rare one indeed! If you like half-life 2 and Bioshock 1&2, you should try this one,

39884049.review:
This game is pretty okay. I'd give it a 6/10 (slightly above average).

The basic shooting and gameplay mechanics are fun. You get some cool segments with the Seeker, which is an explosive sniper rifle where you can control the bullet, and the guns generally feel nice. There are some really excellent cinematic moments. Also, you're the Terminator.

There are a bunch of annoying things, though:
• Enemy variety is pretty weak.
• The... "puzzles", or time-wasters, are just annoying and slow. Moving boxes around and crushing/expanding them to get to different areas is uninteresting. All swimming segments are pointless.
• The TMD powers could be better implemented into gameplay and combat.
• Gun management design isn't very good. They throw random ammo types at you, but realistically you're just going to use two throughout the whole game; upgrading weapons helps enforce that. They also start vomiting generic ammo at you (as well as putting weapon upgrade stations everywhere, at which you can get ammo), so you'll never really have to use more than the two guns you want to.
• The upgrade system is bland and low-impact. Nearing the end of the game, half the upgrades literally become pointless because one of the resource systems is cut out of the game.
• Invisible walls are used everywhere to ensure rather linear movement.

Overall, though, it wasn't a bad 4-5 hours.

"Singularity", es una joya oculta. ¿Por que? Porque es un juego que ha pasado desparecibido por casi la mayor parte de usuarios y/o porque su titulo no ha generado tanto impacto, como se esperaba. 
Si eres amante, de juegos con universos post-apocalipticos, Utopias que se transfroman en Distopía, y acción frenetica con toques de gore (desmembraciones, baños de sangre etc.), este es tu juego. 
Basicamente es como si Activision y RavenSoft hubieran agarrado y fusionado juegos como: Bioshock, Half-Life 2, TimeShift, Call of Duty y You Are Empty, para crear esta joya.  

PROS: 
-Ambientación 
-Paradojas y anomalias, del tiempo y espacio. 
-Buenas dosis de acción 
-Gore 
-Los 3 finales

-Las versiones de Singularity de PS3 y Xbox, traen sistema de logros/trofeos. Me pregunto: ¿por que no implementaron un sistema de logros/trofeos en steam?

Okay well, this certainly was a decent surprise. Got it 75% off, and although I can't quite say it's worth getting at full price, it's certainly a steal on sale.

Okay, first off, believe the other reviews here, it's pretty much a perfect blend of Bioshock, Half-Life 2, and F.E.A.R. . There's no better way to put it. This game oozes with style and atmosphere, and it looks and sounds great. Although the textures and lighting effects leave something to be desired, the rest is flawless (visual-wise).

No bugs, no performance issues, no tank controls, and no pacing snags. Say what you want about the "MEH" textures, at least it's consistent with its framerate. Hell, you can easily increase visual fidelity by forcing 16x anisotropic filtering and overriding the game's antialiasing preset from your GPU driver settings! I used the Nvidia Control Panel 3D Settings options. Usually when I do this, most games will look better but play worse. Singularity? NO PROBLEMO! Nice! Oh and you can also fix the FOV to your liking by getting the free Widescreen Fixer app.

Plot and characters? ... eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeh, ok I guess. Pretty average, and the voice acting could have used more polish... so what makes this game so fun?

The weapon design, the shooting mechanics, and of course the TMD mechanics. Perfect blend. Oh and weapon and TMD upgrades!

Last thing. This game is pretty linear BUT there's quite a fair armount of exploration you can do, and it's pretty darn rewarding!

Hmmmmmmm 7.5/10. Definitely have to play it again some time.

39685614.review:
[h1] This game would be incredible if it wasn't a horrendous console port. [/h1]

Admittedly [b] well-optimized [/b] for high framerates on average hardware (probably because of its tiny texture sizes and weak rendering, even for 2010), but the [b] default field-of-view is locked at 65 degrees [/b][unchangeable even via third party fixes and registry editing] which is [b] motion sickness inducing [/b] even for a console gamer sitting too close to the TV.

Also, the controls are made for a gamepad, meaning RELOAD and USE keybindings are [b] FORCED TO BE BOUND TO THE SAME KEY. [/b] I also have to turn my mouse DPI very low and the game's [b] Mouse Sensitivity to the lowest setting to keep the camera from spinning wildly [/b] at the slightest movement (another symptom of [b] bad console porting [/b]).

[h1] I blame Raven Software for this. [/h1]

[b] They've pulled the FOV garbage and the mouse sensitivity issues with most of their Call of Duty titles [/b] as well, but even those have slightly wider FOV and reasonable keybinding systems.

In addition, the story is very weak and the guns have [b] absolutely no recoil whatsoever [/b]. The viewmodels have recoil animations, but if you hipfire and observe the spread and muzzle climb, you'll see that it is rigid and unmoving. As soon as you realize this and take advantage of it, the game becomes hilariously easy at the highest difficulty.

It's a shame, because there are some wonderful and well-executed (though somewhat derivative) concepts applied to the gameplay (finding the TMD was exciting enough to make me play for another 2 hours, and if it weren't for that I would have quit the game way earlier), but it is all [b] ruined by Activision and Raven's formulaic approach to console-oriented mainstream shooter games. [/b]

The story could have been great, but the answers what could have been a sense of mystery are just force-fed to you in the first 30 minutes. I would have liked an approach where you have to figure it out a bit , especially considering the amount of plot twists in the beginning. I don't know why they felt the need to establish everything at a fast pace through these lengthy, cliche cut scenes and condescending tutorials ("Press C to crouch;" "Press C to stand up;" f*cking really?).

[h1] This game is a loss. [h1]

39675638.review:
Throw Bioshock and Half-Life in a blender, and add some Metro 2033 for flavor. That's this game.

I've had it on my wishlist for ages and finally bit the bullet, scooping it up during one of the times it regularly went on sale. It's certainly worth the price ($8 CAD) for that! I'm very glad I finally did, as it was an entertaining little romp.

It's a couple hours shorter than the first two mentioned games, and about on par with the last, at least if you include poking around for all the various pickups. The story starts out amazing, and the game just [i]drips[/i] atmosphere and dread. Most of it takes place at night and in the rain, giving it  good oppressive atmosphere reminiscent of Ravenholm.

As has been noted though, the story ends up getting a bit light. The intricate world building drops off about half way through, with the audio logs, notes, and tableaus falling by the wayside as the game becomes more and more about the running and gunning. Those things are still there in the latter parts of the game, just not as much. The whole island of Katorga 12 is wonderfully realized, carrying an aesthetic similar to Meto, but with the added bonus of the occasional flashbacks to when it was still intact in 1955.

The overall narrative is serviceable, though nothing to write home about. You're yet another silent protagonist. It keeps to the Half-Life school though, and with a few cutscenes here and there, everything else is in-game. There is a high use of invisible walls in various parts to keep the player on track and from doing things in the proper sequence, but nothing egregious. The mystery of what happened on Katorga 12 was enough to keep me playing through.

Mechanics wise, it's [i]very[/i] easy. The levels are fairly expansive, but progression is linear which helps tell the story. Everything you can interact with glows and your reticle lights up or changes depending on what a particular object can do. You also are able to level up (remember to press Q to actually [b]enable[/b] your TMD perks!) super fast, weapons do a great job shredding enemies, and I found plenty of ammo, cash, and health. Even without knowing I had to enable the TMD perks, I was still rolling in cash and near fully upgraded by the end. Play it on hard, because Normal feels like Easy.

One of the things that I noticed playing through this game was how geared it seemed to be towards achievements (tons of audio logs, perks, weapons upgrades, multiple endings), yet there were none. I am a rather disappointed at the developer for not bothering with proper steam achievement integration. They have it for the console versions, so it shouldn't be different here based on how the vast majority of similar games don't have an issue with them.

Then again, Activision seems to have ignored this game from launch, given its lack of post-release hype, though they seem to have no issue keeping it at $32 CAD even 8 years later. Wait for the sale, because as enjoyable as it is, there's nowhere near enough content for it to be that expensive all these years later.

In the end, I'm happy I finally played Singularity. Calling this game a "greatest hits" collection of other games is pretty accurate. It borrows from a lot of other, games and combines them in a pleasing and fun manner. It's not revolutionary or genera-defining, but it deserves more attention and recognition than it received on launch and in the 8 years since. It's very much a sleeper hit and well worth people's attention.

If you liked Bioshock, Half-Life, or the Metro series, scoop this one up when it's on sale. I think you'll be glad you did.

39673840.review:
Reading the reviews here on Steam would lead you to believe that this game is some amazing hidden gem that is like a mix of Half-Life and Bioshock, and absolutely must be played. Well, seeing those reviews and then seeing the game on sale for $8 made me decide that maybe it was time to try this "hidden gem" of a game out. 
Gameplay wise, what I got was a game that was undeniably fun to play, with game's main "gimmick" so to say actually being a fun tool to use in gameplay, and certianly makes it on par with the gameplay enjoyment of Bioshock and Half Life, and I mean that genuinely. The guns feel great, gameplay is a challenge, and really I had a blast. This game IS fun to play, escpecially on hard difficulty. 
However, one thing that this game is significantly lacking in is story, something those aforementioned games have a great deal of. The game draws you in with an interesting premise and a strong opening, then immediately just throws you on just a linear experience (albiet with a significant portion of exploration) that really has absolutely nothing interesting to say about time travel at all. Yes you travel back to 1955 a few times but really it does not change anything other than make the scenery clean and the soldiers look different. The characters are uninteresting, and really I forgot what I was supposed to be doing story wise at many points. There are audio logs that tell you of what the people on the island experienced after it all went to hell, but really they all amount to saying "I am scared, I am alone, existance is pain, oh no I am going to die".
What's worse is the ending. It's not like Bioshock where your choices throughout the game mean something. It's one of those games where you just go through it and then you get an option to pick what ending you want at the end. It's literally the worst way to do an ending (looking at you Farcry 3) and this game has 3 whole options for it. And really, you know how I mentioned Farcry 3 having a choice ending, well at least your charcter is voiced in that game and he has moral reasoning to either option he chooses. In Singularity, your charcter has no voiced actor, in fact all he has is a name, there is literally nothing special about him personality wise at all, and yet the game makes him face an ethical and moral dilemna to literally choose the fate of the human race at the end of the game anyway. Nothing is learned at all. It pissed me off.
So really, in the end, this game is fun to play, and has a pulp fiction story that is so weak it was probably just written into the game after the devs realized they needed a creative backdrop for their awesome combat system they thought of. Whatver you read, this game is not something special, and really it's forgettable. No wonder Raven Studios just helps with Call of Duty game development now because this just proves they are garbage at story but are really good creating a system of shooting at things.

39600116.review:
I played this game when it first came out and enjoyed the hell out of it. It was, at that time, one of my favorites. I recently rediscovered this and I'm so glad that now I have it on steam.

The game is centered around captain Renko, an american officer sent to an imaginary Katorga-12 island, in the USSR. You find out that the island was used to recover and use a powerful element, the E-99, that got out of control and unleashed hell.

The pros:
- Awesome story, even if it's 7-8 hours of gameplay.
- Multiple endings depending on whatever you want to believe/think it's better through the game.
- Fun gameplay - you can use a soviet experimental equipment (TMD) to alter the objects' age, to age enemies and open time rifts.
- Shooting zombies and mutants is always fun.
- Some good boss fights (not that challenging, but fun and interesting).
- Some little jumpscares (nothing that horror to keep you awake at night, just enough to make it interesting)
- The overall atmosphere is haunting, especially when you get the flashbacks from the past - similar to Metro.
- An overall dark, interesting game.

The cons:
- NO SUBTITLES. I cannot emphasize on this enough. Given the fact that this game is story-oriented, has a lot of technical and scientific explanations and has audio recordings left on your path so you can better understand what's going on, the fact that it does not have subtitles is infuriating.
- Also, to support the biggest con of this game, the settings are too basic. You cannot get the voices up and turn the SFX down. No, you can turn only the SFX and music up and down, so the voices will still get lost somehow. You just need to turn up the volume when someone talks.
- Some optimization problems.

39271508.review: (Warning: Contains Spoilers) In my humble opinion, Singularity is kind of like a Russian Half-Life 2, which is one hell of a compliment if you think about it, but there are some key differences, which I will get into shortly. You step onto the Russian island of Katorga-12, to find that things have gone to shit VERY quickly. Most of the island's inhabitants have either died or mutated into fearsome creatures with some unique abilities. As Captain Nathaniel Renko, your job is to set things right, by preventing dictator Demichev from achieving world dominance at the expense of Katorga-12 and its inhabitants. Time travel is a key factor throughout the otherwise linear fashion, as Renko breaches history multiple times in order to destroy the Singularity. The onslaught of mutants is broken up by attacks from Demichev's decidedly human henchman, which makes for a nice change of pace. Just like the Gravity Gun, the unique tool of Singularity is the TMD or Time Manipulation Device. With it, you can freeze time, age enemies until they turn to dust, or blast them with your impulse function. My only gripe is that the TMD's full potential, just like the "Supercharged Gravity Gun" are unlocked a bit late in the game. One thing that I came to appreciate on my second playthrough was the story: the harrowing ordeal of going back in time multiple times, only to reveal that Demichev has outsmarted you and your incompetent ally Barisov at the very end. Personally, as opposed to allowing Demichev to rule the world or Barisov to take his place, I killed them both and allowed the world to fall into chaos, only to return as a ruthless warlord weilding the TMD. The story can be, I grant you, confusing at times, but the TMD and Katorga-12's guns and monsters make Singularity a great game. If you loved Half-Life, you'll really appreciate this game. Overall Score: 9.8/10

The beauty of Singularity is in the fact that it isn't a generic FPS where you just shoot anything and everything. It coveres pretty much a major spectrum of gaming. You can grab a shotgun and go blasting, get a minigun and shred everything, go for precision kills with a sniper, shoot bullets that you can control, OR, just sneak around and not shoot anyone at all. 

The mechanics of time manipulation are pretty solid for a game in its time, but maybe a bit confusing as is with any game that deals with time travel.  The combat mechanics using time manipulation is pretty interesting.

The story is pretty solid, and flexible, with multiple ending based on your choice. Combat is pretty straightforward, although it can be pretty annoying at times with them swarming you or jumping through time.

I'd say the game is a lost gem of its time.

38028307.review:
The concept of Singularity is very interesting - being able to leap through time and change the past so that you can alter the present and prevent catastrophic events in the future. The setting of the game is similarly captivating; you and a team of U.S Marines are dispatched to an abandoned ex-Soviet island called 'Kotorga 12' to investigate a recent anomalous EM surge.

What makes this game so horrible is that it's not fun to play because the enemies are easy to kill, there's a lack of enemy variety, the majority of the weapons (the Seeker notwithstanding) are boring and the levelling system effectively boils down to being able to kill bullet-sponge enemies faster. Combined with no memorable characters and a horror atmosphere almost completely negated by bad AI as well as the aforementioned criticisms, Singularity does not do justice to the premise at all.

It's a shame. These kinds of games are always irritating because there's great conceptualisation, yet in bringing it to a game format they've managed to bury it in shallow and repetitive gameplay. 

Whilst I heavily do not recommend this game, I still firmly believe that a game like this could be great if it addresses said gameplay issues and involves more memorable and likeable characters.

I desperately needed a break. a Break in the form of a tight and well scripted action roller coaster with time travel, time manipulation and soviet era aesthetics.

37292332.review:
I enjoyed this game playing from start to finish, something that you could expect to take the better part of a day to do.  The story follows a Spec Ops soldier Renko on a mission to the island of katorga-12 off the coast of Russia.  There, he encounters a time anomaly that sends him back into a burning building, where he saves a man's life.  This man goes on to conquer the world under Soviet rule.  Thanks, Renko.  The rest of the story is exploring the island with the Time Manipulation Device (TMD) to try to fix things, all while gunning down the mutated denizens of the island and the flow of soldiers from the new dictator's regime sent to stop you.  

In terms of gameplay, the game is Half-life mixed with Bioshock.  The TMD is both your gravity gun and your plasmids, being useful in puzzle solving and combat, and usable alongside your firearm.  You can explore the levels to find more E-99 (read: ADAM) and use those to upgrade your weapons and character.  Gunplay is right out of Bioshock, with varied enemy types that require different approaches, and very satisfying.  Using the TMD to remove or create cover, or to create a bubble of slowed time is genuinely fun.  Certain levels just scream Half-life though, to such an extent that I was wondering at one point if an ichthyosau-like monster was going to dwell in the water.

The game is quite easy on normal, and the puzzles are solvable with the expected tools.  Level creation is a bit shoddy in parts, relying on invisible walls often as not to prevent unitended exploration.  Though the character upgrades are a bit more interesting, all weapons have the same three upgrades with two levels each, so they lose a little personality compared to bioshock.  The major complaint would be the controls in the upgrade screen requiring the use of arrow keys and forbidding the mouse.  

Solid game for $15.00 on a steam sale.  If you liked Bioshock and Half-life, this will feel like a good purchase.

37091052.review: «Singularity» — достаточно средний шутер, который взял очень много из других игр, тем не менее, имеющий свои интересные фишки, и что самое удивительное неплохой сюжет. В принципе, «Singularity»  легко описывается как такой линейный «BioShock» для бедных.  Но это не так уж плохо. Технически, «Singularity» это голый «Unreal Engine 3» без приукрашиваний, что для 2010 года хорошо, но сейчас конечно все это выглядит несколько устаревшим. Хотя мне картинка в целом понравилась. Атмосфера чувствуется, правда в основном лишь в первые часы, кстати, для любопытных разбросаны аудио дневники. «Raven Software» постарались разнообразить кампанию, все время подкидывая что-то новенькое и необычное. Есть RPG составляющая, несколько разновидностей врагов включая боссов и кое-что интересное в  пушках. Но сама стрельба и оружие плохо ощущаются, что несомненно минус для шутера. Враги также мягко говоря не блещут интеллектом. Из хорошего, помимо упомянутого сюжета: в «Singularity» интересный сеттинг, дизайнеры неплохо поработали над локациями, но самое главное это "МВП"  одной из функций которого "омалаживание" или  "cостаривание" некоторых объектов. Очень необычный и оригинальный элемент, по началу развлекает, и поможет вам в решении головоломок. Но вообще у "МВП" широкий набор функционала, без которого порой никуда. Игра оставила приятные впечатления, рекомендую любителям сингловых шутеров. Оценка: 7,5 из 10.

36878775.review:
An fps from 2010 that gets criminally overlooked nowadays. It's hard to decribe Singularity perfectly, but all the unique abilties and weapons come together to form a campy romp through familair territory with a few surprises along the way.

Here's the positives:

The most interesting part of this game is easily the TMD (Time Manuipulation Device), which adds extra layers to gunfights and makes combat a real treat instead of the usual shooter affair of "shoot the guys until they're all dead". Without going into too much detail, the TMD allows you to do everything from aging your enemies to dust to creating a bubble where time is slowed to a crawl. It adds a lot of dynamic features to fighting and I honestly wish there was more game just so I could keep playing with the fantastic uses of the TMD.

While the starter weapons are fairly standard pistol, rifle, shotgun etc., the weapons that come later on are nothing short of inspired. One of the most interesting comes in the form of a sniper rifle that allows you to steer the bullets into your enemies, and it never gets old! Although there are only a little over 10 weapons over the course of the game, they all become a lot of fun in combination with the TMD as well as feeling nice to use on their own.

There is also an upgrade system called "hero perks" to give your character more health, extra ammo for weapons, more power in TMD abilties and so on, but it's a minor feature that doesn't have a lot of unique stuff going on, it serves primarily to scale your power to meet the growing difficulty curve of the game. There's also the abiltiy to upgrade your weapons to reload faster, do more damage and other standard power upgrades, but again, there's nothing too unique about it.

Now on to the negatives:

The game seems to move really fast through some of its areas. There were genuinely interesting ideas or gimmicks that I wanted to see utilized longer, especially when it comes to the monsters, as there are a lot of specialized monsters that only appear in one area of the game and then disappear for the rest of the game. Speaking of length, I finished the singeplayer campaign in 7 hours, which is a little light for games of its kind. 

My other major complaint is that the upgrades offered for weapons and the hero perks felt boring. Not bad necessarily, I still made sure to be on the lookout for hidden perks I could discover in the world beause I genuinely wanted to find them all. However, the overall premise could have been expanded into something more interesting. The real bulk of my problem comes from the fact that the upgrades really didn't feel that impactful. They did improve the weapons, yes, but because it's not possible to upgrade every weapon in every way, I found myself prioritizing specific wepaons I liked best and by the end of the game only using those weapons because they were simply better than the others since they had upgrades.

Overall though, this game is still worth checking out for combining some really unique features together to make a fun shooter in a pretty cool location. If I had to give it a score, I'd give it a 7/10. Get it on sale though, the price is way to high for what you're getting.

Gioco inaspettatamente vario, originale che mi ha tenuto incollato per diverse ore. E' un fps di stampo fantascientifico, con balzi nel tempo, con una tecnologia (CMT) che si manifesta attraverso un guanto che ti permette ad esempio di invecchiare o ringiovanire oggetti; si puo' anche usare sui nemici e l'effetto è quello di farli morire per invecchiamento rapido; inoltre sposta oggetti, li prende e li lancia, lancia un raggio di energia per stordire i nemici, crea delle bolle temporali per dilatare il tempo.
Il gioco possiede anche una leggera connotazione di survival/horror che lo rende piu' vario. Inoltre talvolta per andare avanti occorre risolvere alcuni enigmi.
Le armi e la tecnologia CMT si possono potenziare durante il gioco.
Mi aspettavo un fps come tanti ma è uno fra i migliori a cui ho giocato.
Fortemente consgliato. Talvolta si trova per pochi euro.

36603085.review:
>>> Проверено! Идет на Win 10!
>>> Проверено! Рекомендую играть на высшем уровне сложности.
>>> Проверено! В сети можно найти рабочий русификатор. Локализация - на твердую 6,5 из 10. К самому переводу в целом притензий нет, но вот голоса могли бы и получше подобрать.

Вот знаете... скучна жизнь человека, который ценит сюжетные шутеры от первого лица. Индустрия из года в год не может удивить его, ведь новых "ААА" сюжетных шутеров практически не появляется. Т.е. есть либо звездные ААА, либо "второй эшелон", либо вообще протухшие проходняки... все новые франшизы как правило выступают во второй группе.

Как бы то не было - Singularity ВНЕЗАПНО оказался ближе к звездным сюжетным ААА-шутерам (FEAR, HL2, Doom3...), чем к играм "второго эшелона" (Area51, Alpha Prime, D. N. Forever...). Что же такого удивительного может предложить игра?

[b]Во-первых:[/b] это игрообращующая фича - "Мобильный Временной Преобразователь". Геймплей завязан на использовании этого чудо-девайса не хуже, чем геймплей Half-Life 2 на "Фомке" и "Гравицапе". Юзать его можно и нужно часто, разнообразно и со вкусом.
[b]Во-вторых:[/b] это действительно проработанные противники. Монстров которые как зомби тупо бегут к вам тут нет. У каждого есть какая-то фича: одни кидаются в вас предметами интерьера, мимо других можно аккуратно проползти в стелсе... и так далее (не хочу особо спойлерить).
[b]В-третьих:[/b] сеттинг, постановка и декорации. Как бы да - клюква здесь цветет так, что иногда начинает скатываться в дикий треш, но все же нужно отдать разрабам должное: вселенная (для шутера на 8 часов) получилась ОЧЕНЬ проработанная, персонажи и ситуации интересные.

Что еще? В игре есть приятная прокачка. Собираем канистры с мутагеном, на полученные очки покупаем почти читерские способности. Впрочем - покупать никто не заставляет, да и сбор хлопот не доставляет (игра очень коридорна, все на виду).

Итог? Всем любителям шутеров настоятельно рекомендую данную игру. Однозначно годнота... с несколькими концовками.

36231478.review:
What starts out as a straight forward first person shooter quickly turns into a neat blend of [b]Half-Life 2[/b] (gameplay) and [b]BioShock[/b] (storytelling). The shootouts are fun with great gamepad contols while time and gravity manipulation make [b]Singularity[/b] stand out from the crowd. Unfortunately the game's second half tends to be way too easy on medium difficulty albeit still being enjoyable due to the fun mechanics. The story starts out interesting but turns out to be way less clever than it wishes it were – almost like the first [b]BioShock[/b], yet less pretentious and without the mediocre gameplay inbetween.

If you're susceptible to motion sickness, the head-bob and narrow FOV will cause issues, though the FOV-Fix from flawlesswidescreen.org can alleviate the problem. Seasoned FPS players should play this on hard difficulty, especially when playing with mouse and keyboard.

Bottom line: If you like [b]Half-Life 2[/b] for its mechanics, [b]Singularity[/b] is a must-play.

36220917.review:
This is a straight-forward shooter with only a single choice: Which end sequence you want to watch.
The strange part about this is that I have played through it 4 times. This might be my favourite FPS game until DOOM came out in 2016. 

There really isn't too much to go into though, as the game plays like every other shooter except for a big difference: The TMD, or time manipulation device.
Aside from winning the title of "most obviously named  game item", it is really really fun to use. It functions similar to spells in elder scrolls games in that it has energy seperate from your guns and follows different rules. The cool thing is that it is used in many many places.
The TMD can do anything from age your enemies right before your eyes, to making item containers new again so you can loot whatever was in it all those years ago. Don't count on it winning you the whole game though, because even though it is  powerful it has limited charges and some enemies are immune to your attacks.

The game has a really diverse range of settings despite always taking place in the same island town somewhere near Russia. This is because you are on a research station with a broken time research station, and the singularity in the center forces you to often switch between the current day and the time that the research lab had the major accident. Along the way from the harbor to the laboratory in the center you will see ghosts of the past haunting the town, which gives the game a really mysterious feeling. The exploration aspect is really well done and makes you want to search every tiny corner.
The game also rewards you well for doing this, because the experience isn't gained by killing monsters but by finding the in-game currency in the form of E-99 containers and upgrade kits. 

The story itself is pretty good, and at the end you get a real head scratcher that will make you really wonder what the right choice in this situation will be. It's kind of a reward for all the "go here do this" that the other 99% of the game are.

The combat system is really fun for a FPS game. Not only can you find interesting ways to defeat enemies with your hand-held time warper, but each weapon has a unique function that you can expand upon with weapon upgrade crates.


To find out if you love this game is easy:
Do you love games like Bioshock, DOOM and other linear shooters with few weapons but interesting mechanics? Then this game is for you.

If you want a shooter that gives you freedom and lets you explore a world at your own pace like Borderlands, then this is a game to avoid.

36133767.review:
Singularity is a very unique and very fun twist on the traditional first person shooter. The enemies vary between intimidating and scary as shit and all over varrying degrees of challenge. The Easy difficulty setting still makes for a scary game, but higher levels are much more challenging. It's not all horror though, there are a good number of sections that play out like a military/sci-fi shooter. The story is awesome and deals havily with time travel and unique problem solving puzzles based on the temporal manipulation of objects and the enivornment using the TMD (Time Manipulation Device). You age things to destroy/remove them, or you "revert" them to their original state to make use of them. Weapons are satisfying and sexy and the satisfaction of sniping an enemies head off while in slow motion and seeing the gratuitous (yet probably unrealistic) fountain of spurting blood is just terrific. Voice acting is very good too and includes the talent of Steve Blum, famous for Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, the Call of Duty series, Warcraft III, World of Warcraft, Company of Heroes, StarCraft II, Diablo III,  and so many other games, as well as the show Star Wars: Rebels. 
I would add that much of the game is inspired by an earlier Raven Software game, Wolfenstein (2009). Much of the set design and overall gameplay is very similar with upgradable weapons and abbilities and creepy supernatrual crap, and the TMD is also very similar to the Thule Medallion from Wolfenstein. The primary antagonists, the Russians of the Soviet Union could also be seen as analogous to the Nazis. But the game is very fun and challenging so I will not go as far as to call this lazy game design....but it does come close.

36078327.review:
Now, fitting to the Halloween sale i rediscovered the game.

Be Captain Renko, stuck in an alternate timeline with mutants and angry soviets.
Your best ally is a Time Manipulation Device, allowing you to age objeyts and entities or revert their state to normal. But wait, there is more! The TMD allows you to find secret stashes and hidden upgrades. You need everything you can find to reach the end of the game. You will have a basic selection of weapons as well as some exotic ones.

Without spoiling too much, the games plot is more interesting than in other shooting games, the game world will tell youa lot about the background of the story, either as audiotape or written note on the wall, paper or ground. There is much to see, but you will hardly deviate from the main playing tube. There might be some branching ways, but they are mostly dead ends, typical shooting game. These dead ends usually hold he more valuable items and interesting notes.

What matters a lot to me is the game world and this game got it right. You are on a vacant island, with industrial and scientific relics spread all around the place. The game gets this pretty right. It introduces you to the island by walking you through the residential part, filled with stories and impressions of life before the local disaster.

Well, the game does not look all too bad after all these years, no idea if the multiplayer part still works. The games core mechanics, shooting anyone who does not produce a green crosshair works well, the AI is, lets say from a different time. The game can be challenging, even on easy.

You need to solve small puzzles every then and now, either to move to the next area or get some upgrade material.
Speaking of upgrades, you will collect E99-Tech, you need it for improvements to your TMD and your character. You will also find weapon kits, allowing you to increase damage, reload speed and clip size of your weapons.

So, if you have 4,99€ left and want a sometimes creepy game, the amount of jumpscares is minimal, get this one.

A little warning, it might be related to the low field of view, i get tired rather fast playing this game. Not sure if you suffer the same fate...

36057525.review:
PROS:

- The game is great in concept.
- Looks great for an older game.
- Top-notch voice acting.
- Weapons are beautiful works of art. 
- TMD (Time Manipulation Device) is cool-looking and has many uses.
- Storyline is interesting.
-Mixes science with guns, my favorite combo in games.
-The weapons, while beautiul, are extremely functional. the Time-Dilation Sniper Rifle and Seeker Rifles are my favorites.

CONS:
-Hardly ever goes on sale.
-Some enemies are annoying to fight. Phase Ticks are frustrawting because they ignore your bullets and are designed to drain your TMD power. The tree-root things  just spam the same powerful and destructive attack and no amount of hiding or Deadlocking will stop you from dying. it's really based on luck.
-Sometimes it isn't always clear where I need to go. I know the "ping pathing" button exists but whenever do I think of using it? The game never suggests it only in early levels where  exploration is basic.
-No achievements! Trading cards I can do without. But no achievements? Even Metro 2033 has achievements and so does Half-Life 2!
-Some areas where you are meant to progress aren't always clear on what you need to do; provide no hints, and force you to do things the hard way, forcing you to spend more time on "solving problems" than you need to.

Despite these things I recommend someone at least try it. It''s one of those one-shot FPS games that are really fun but ultimately never see a sequel.

36057355.review:
Отличный тир вроде Bulletstorm. Ужастик с пост советской атмосферой. Очень много технопанковского стиля и откровенной клюквы. Несмотря на попытки напугать играется как комедия без закадрового смеха. 

Игра сплошные плюсы, но есть и немного минусов в виде деревянного искусственного идиота (ИИ) и крайне скудной серо коричнево ржавой палитры красок. Локации ОЧЕНЬ тесные и коридорность практически давит на психику. Форменно, иногда уровень это кишка из коридоров и лесенок шириной в два шага. 

Но если учитывать цену по скидке размером с меню в макдаке, то игра однозначно стоящая. 

Отдельно стоит отметить веселые способности девайса на левой руке героя, которые позаимствованы из серии Bioshock. В перемешку с неслабым арсеналом оружия и возможностью его улучшения, истребление всего мутировавшего, но все еще живого, очень увлекательно. 

Покупайте, не пожалеете. 
З.Ы. по сюжету игры у СССР были технологии перемещения во времени, работающих на крайне радиоактивном и токсичном элементе Е99. После подобного никаких претензий к серьезности происходящего можно не предъявлять.

Honestly, first impression was not good. I began to play and I thought: "Omg there is no map, no inventory, no anything which is mandatory in modern FPS, saves at checkpoints .." + Amazing story and overall atmosphere

- Player interface is simple (no map and other modern perks)
- Saving at checkpoint
-/+ Not sure if this is good or not. The game is pretty much linear, there is no backtracking at all, once you get to the other part, you are not allowed to go back. First I was a bit annoyed by it, but after some time I got to used to it and even liked it.

35968929.review:
Es fühlt sich an wie Bioshock in Russland. Das Spiel ist leider voller Momente, die etwas cheesy sind und Singularity schafft es nicht dieselbe Tiefe an Atmosphere aufzubauen, wie Bioshock. Gerade nach Bioshock Infinite gibt es extrem viele Parallelen in den spielen, mit Zeitrissen und alternativen Realitäten. Die Waffen sind teils wirklich witzig, wie der Seeker, doch teils auch ziemlicher Schrott, wie die Pistole, mit der ich scheinbar nicht einmal ein Scheunentor treffe, selbst wenn es zwei Meter vor mir ist. Vielleicht liegt es auch an mir, aber ich fühle mich besser bei dem Gedanken, dass es womöglich die Waffe ist. Ansonsten gibt es viele sehr vorraussehbare Events. 
"Oh, ein Vorsprung den ich runterspringen muss, den ich aber danach nicht mehr hoch kann? Nicht, dass mich sofort ein neuer Gegnertyp angreift, sobald ich runterspringe" <lädt Schrotflinte durch> 
Also ist es ein schlechtes Spiel? Nein. Es hat durchaus seine Momente und die Atmosphere ist da, wenn auch etwas holprig. Also wer der Meinung ist, das Bioshock etwas zu wenig Kommunismus hat, der fühlt sich hier gut aufgehoben.

35912687.review:
Definitely a cult classic.

I played this game on the 360 a year or two after it came out, and I thought it was amazing. Played it this year (late-2017), and I still find it fun to play, especially the multiplayer (which sadly, is dead now)

---

My only critique is that the gameplay itself has not aged well. With the current generation of games being made with mostly open world, exploration, survival, and/or very large variety of stuff n' things, Singularity seems very strange and primitive with it's linear "point A to point B" level design (with a small hint of exploration--similar to Half Life 2), low variety of weapons, and some repeated puzzles. Although there is a small variety of weapons, they all feel different and unique.

There is a large variety of enemies as well, all of which have their own special perks to them.

The story of the game is pretty easy to follow. Though there are a few confusing sections, most, if not all plotholes are eventually filled. The games scenery is also gorgeous. The world feels real, raw, and devastating.

---

I'd personally rate this game a 7/10. Gunplay is satisfying, story is alright, mapping and scenery are amazing, and the price ($30) is alright in my book.






























This game is especially good for an Activision published game. I'd say its Activisions last good game, as of October 22nd, 2017. I personally wouldn't mind a sequel.

35803166.review:
Singularity ist ein Spiel der verpassten Möglichkeiten.

Das Spiel bietet so viele interessante Ansätze, eine Gravitygun, morphen alt <->  neu, Zeitwaffen, Zeitspünge, etc. So viele Möglichkeiten für Rätsel und Effekte. Nur leider wird dieses Potential kaum in das Spiel integriert. Am Ende ist es ein sehr linearer Shooter mit einigen wenigen, sich wiederholenden Rätseln. Und gab es im ganzen Spiel wirklich nur zwei Bossfights?
Man spürt, dass hinter dem Spiel gute Ideen standen, diese wurden aber leider nicht konsequent umgesetzt, weder in der Story noch im Gameplay. Am Ende gibt es die Wahl zwischen drei Schlusssequenzen, aber auch dies wirkte auf mich irgendwie aufgesetzt.

Singularity ist ein solider Shooter der in ca. 7h durchgespielt ist. Auch wenn die Zeitmanipulation auf den ersten Blick interessant klingt, wird daraus kein bedeutendes Spielelement. Dem Spiel fehlt somit ein Alleinstellungsmerkmal.

35625758.review:
[h1]Questo rende possibile viaggiare nel tempo... Il flusso canalizzatore![/h1]

[b]PRO[/b]
[list]
    [*]Trama eccellente
    [*]Gameplay vario
    [*]Comparto tecnico di ottimo livello (considerando l'anno 2010)
    [*]Il congegno CMT è impagabile
[/list]

[b]CONTRO[/b]
[list]
    [*]Un pò troppo lineare (se paragonato a Crysis e Bioshock, tanto per citare alcuni coetanei)
    [*]Poco longevo
    [*]Il massimo livello di difficoltà, Difficile, è discretamente facile
[/list]

[h1]PERCHE' ACQUISTARLO[/h1]
Singularity esce in sordina nel 2010 e pochi se ne accorgono e tuttavia è una svista non giustificata (ho finito il gioco 2 volte...tanto per dimostrarne la bontà).
La trama ed il gameplay sono piacevoli e vanno a rimescolare meccaniche già viste e tuttavia il titolo risulta scorrevole e divertente, mai noioso. Il comparto tecnico è inoltre di ottimo livello.
L'ambientazione l'ho trovata eccellente (mi è venuto il dubbio che Katorga 12 fosse esistita veramente!).

[h1]COSA NON VA[/h1]
Il gioco va su binari prestabiliti che si snodano si attraverso location interessanti ma non vi è libero arbitrio nell'esplorazione (inoltre ambienti appena visti vengono isolati nel momento in cui passate alla stanza/area successiva, quindi non potrete tornare indietro).
In aggiunta il gioco è veramente poco longevo (l'ho finito in due serate): da parte mia è stato un bene dato che venivo dalla "traumatica" e faticosa esperienza di Dead Space ma posso capire che non tutti vogliano tempi di gioco così ridotti (soprattutto quando, come in questo caso, le meccaniche del gioco sono veramente divertenti e si vorrebbe investire più tempo).
Infine il gioco è relativamente semplice: a livello Difficile morirete poche volte.

[h1]INTRODUZIONE[/h1]
Rawen software è stato spesso sinonimo di qualità per quanto concerne gli FPS e Singularity non è quindi da meno: un bel FPS fantascientifico dove sfrutterete dei poteri particolari per viaggiare nel tempo, tra gli accadimenti avvenuti sull'isola di Katorga-12 nel 1955 ed il presente, il 2010.

[h1]STORIA[/h1]
Un bel giorno, o voi dello spionaggio statunitense, vi accorgete che sull'isola di Katorga-12 in Siberia qualcosa di anomalo sta succedendo, con emissioni di radiazioni fuori dalla norma. E che fare se non mandare in missione una squadra di marines ad investigare (in veste non ufficiale naturalmente) sugli eventi che stanno accadendo sull'isola?
Naturalmente poi un impulso radioattivo vi farà precipitare a picco sull'isola poco prima dell'arrivo e lì scoprirete pian piano i misteriosi accadimenti che avvennero nel lontano 1955 e che ancora si ripercuotono nel presente.
In particolare, nel 1955 durante il pieno della guerra fredda, i russi scoprirono un nuovo elemento radioattivo dalle potenzialità infinite, E-99. Tale elemento avrebbe permesso di costruire ordigni nucleari eccezionalmente potenti, di alterare il ciclo di vita degli esseri viventi (animali e piante) ed infine di manipolare lo spazio/tempo. 
Fantastico direte voi...si peccato che naturalmente non sia facile gestire tale potere e quindi il più classico degli incidenti (nel 1955) provocherà danni inenarrabili.

Voi siete Nate Renko e vivete nel 2010 e fate parte dello spionaggio americano... e tuttavia qualcuno si ricorda di voi nel 1955...e non siete cambiato in 50 anni...e durante l'esplosione del 1955 avete cambiato il flusso del tempo prendendo una decisione azzardata che modificherà, su quella linea temporale, la storia dell'umanità...l'avete fatto piccolo il danno insomma...

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Singularity prende spunto dai grandi classici del passato contemporaneo (Crysis e soprattutto Bioshock e Dead Space per la tensione in alcuni punti, ma mai raggiungendo i picchi di quest'ultimo) sfornando un bel FPS, piacevole da giocare.

E' un gioco action, non di sopravvivenza: troverete tante armi, tanti medikit e quindi il vostro approccio sarà di andare all'arrembaggio.

Accanto alle tradizionali armi (pistola,mitra,shotgun,etc) avrete in aggiunta il CMT, un fantastico congegno che ha il potere di permettere il viaggio nel tempo tramite le singolarità e far viaggiare gli oggetti nel tempo! Il risultato? Una scala distrutta torna agli antichi fasti, un soldato in carne ed ossa viene invece carbonizzato, un ponte crollato torna in perfetto stato in pochi secondi, una nave affondata riaffiora in superficie in perfetta efficienza.....un'arma fantastica quindi!

Potrete poi spendere i classici punti bonus per potenziare il CMT appunto, le armi che avete o migliorare la vostra salute, la durata degli scatti etc.

Tutto questo vi terrà impegnati per 2 serate intense (poche ore quindi). Giocatelo come dico sempre al massimo livello di difficoltà (che comunque è discretamente facile).

[h1]COMPARTO TECNICO[/h1]
Considerando che il gioco è uscito nel 2010, ancora oggi si comporta egregiamente ed è piacevole da giocare. Bella la grafica, buona la colonna sonora ed effetti audio ben calibrati (per creare un pò di suspance). Ottima la risposta ai comandi (mouse e tastiera naturalmente).

[h1]CONCLUSIONI[/h1]
Vi ricordate Biff Tannen (Ritorno al Futuro, il 2 in particolare)? Ecco, il buon vecchio Biff rubava l'almanacco sportivo portandolo al suo lui del 1955 ed in questo modo il futuro veniva cambiato..con Biff che diventava l'uomo più ricco del mondo...

Ecco....voi farete l'errore di modificare qualcosa nel passato ed andando nel futuro finirete sul flusso del tempo da voi modificato!
Si perché non darete naturalmente ascolto alla vecchia regola di viaggiare nel tempo ma non toccare nulla, non fare nulla...non alterare in alcun modo il futuro...no...
Va beh direte voi...poco male....si...se non fosse che l'Unione Sovietica governa il mondo intero nel flusso temporale da voi modificato..

Volete quindi riparare al danno da voi compiuto? Giocate a questo bel gioco (che prende citazioni chiaramente anche da Ritorno al Futuro) e scoprirete come finirà il mondo (avrete tre possibili finali).

35608011.review:
This game is on the "pretty good" end of the "average" spectrum.

While it's no replacement for Bioshock, it does a serviceable job in filling that role nonetheless. The powers are fun and, despite a low variety, give combat more pizazz then pure gunfighting. The time machanic is completely original and works very well, but I do wish that they had done more with it.

One big problem worth noting (besides the lack of subtitles--like seriously wtf) is that the difficulty is pretty much all over the place. For the first two hours you'll have only the wrench, but for the last two hours your timepiece will have infinite instakill ammo. Speckled in between are poorly paced, irregular, and inconsistent difficulty spikes.

Overall, I liked this game. However, if you're not a huge fan of the Bioshock series, from which this derives most of its gameplay and story elements, you probably won't see the appeal here.

Also: Singularity is super short. All things considered, I would not recommend buying it at full price or even the price I got it for. Use G2A if you're interested.

35584543.review:
Good game. Fun  and interesting story line. A linear shooter, don't expect any exploration. I did enjoy the travel back forth in time and the resulting consequences this has in the future, although, altering the past seems to have little real impact on the future. Certainly, the plot introduces several paradoxes that are conceptually difficult to overcome.


Combat is pleasing and much better done than most modern FPS even though this game is already 7 years old. Weapons are satisfying, however, I felt like there was no realy skill based progression even though the game has this option. I'd have prefered that skill points distribution was left out entirely. The game became too easy about midway through..The AI is 1 demensional and strategically under developed. 

Try it out, it only takes 6 hours to complete.

35430924.review:
So I finally finished Singularity.  I'm mixed.  I'll give it a thumbs-up with the caveat that this is a good game to get on sale but I wouldn't pay full price for it.

Singularity has a really interesting concept, with a story that sees you shifting back and forth between 1955 and 2010.  Your actions in 1955 affect the game world in 2010 and as you go through the game a lot of your progression comes from gaining and upgrading abilities that affect time itself in some manner.  For a non-cartoony game it still looks surprisingly good too.

Singularity's gameplay feels quite dated.  The great majority of the game consists of moving from one arena to another with one-way drops and doors in between.  Sometimes it's corridors.  Sometimes it's an open outdoorsy area.  Sometimes it's a fortified position with huge waves of enemies and the gun you need to deal with them just happens to lying right in front of you.  Also, if you're paying attention the game drops enough hints about the story that it starts to feel like you're carrying an idiot ball in which stupidity in the only option if you want to progress.  All-in-all it feels very formulaic and on-rails.  That's not to say it's bad, merely that it feels very much a 2010 shooter.

Solid Old School FPS with a nice storyline.
The main character is given an item called Time Manipulation Device (TMD) which let's you do a lot of interesting things to progress in your campaign as well as get some new ways to kill your enemies.
You can literally age things (and enemies) with the TMD which is amazing.
You have an arsenal of some regular weapons and some fantastic big guns (like the Seeker, it let's you control the way the bullet travels, that is very fun to use).
You are also able to upgrade your weapons and the TMD.
The characters and the dialogues are well done.

I feel like this game is underrated.
Definitely recommended, especially to Doom/Wolfenstein fans.

35035748.review:
Historia

Estamos en plena guerra fria, la Unión Sovietica (La gloriosa Unión Sovietíca) descubre en una isla un nuevo elemento con el cual pretenden conquistar el mundo. Depués de un enorme pico de radiación ya en pleno 2010 que estropea uno de los satélites de EEUU, estos envian a un comando para ver que demonios pasa ahí.


Sobre el juego:

-FPS con ligeros toques de "miedo".
-Tiene multijugado (el cual no he probado ni probaré   
-Sobre las 9 horas en dificil
-Principal característica, lo siento pero se me olvidó el nombre, un brazalete capaz de alterar el tiempo de las cosas.
-Hasta donde yo se, 3 finales diferentes
-El juego cuenta con distintos potenciadores, tanto de armas, como de vida, enermiga y ventajas (Recuperar vida, que tu energia se recargue etc)

Lo que me ha gustado:

-Esas fases de "miedo" con los mutantes.
-Los propios mutantes, siempre es un placer matar bichos feos.
-Las opciones del Brazalete (Creo que se llamaba DMT) capaces de alterar el tiempo de algunas cosas.
-La historia, es pasable, tiene viajes en el tiempo.
-Botiquines y algunas armas "Inventadas" interesantes.

Lo que no me ha gustado:

-Pienso que el juego podía haber ofrecido mas, la premisa del brazalete (DMT) es muy interesante pero sus funciones son muy limitadas, por poner un ejemplo: Puedes controlar cajas o bidones, los controlas como si fueran poderes mentales pero esto mismo no puedes hacerlo con los enemigos.
-Físicas muy toscas, lo dicho, muy desaprovechada la idea del DMT    
-El solo poder llevar 2 armas, esto es un fallo grave porque quieres llevar mas armas pero al final optas por lo mas práctico que es el rifle de asalto y la escopeta. Yo por ejemplo solo he provado algunas armas para terminar soltándolas y llevando lo de siempre. 
-Pienso que el juego debería tener un cuarto final, que serían las 4 situaciones que se presentarian al final.


Conclusión:

Singularity es uno de esos chuters mediocres (esto no es malo para nada, es mas soy fan de este tipo de juegos) que intentan ofrecer algo nuevo pero se queda a medio camino. La historia es interesante y el juego "funciona" a mi me ha parecido interesante la verdad.

34871185.review:
***READ THIS***
This is not a fully-polished, AAA game.  I encountered a couple of "rookie" mistakes in the design, and at one point an important NPC just up and disappeared!  (Thankfully, I didn't need him in order to progress)

That being said, Singularity is WELL worth the play.  A good blend of challenging encounters, mixed with opportunities for you to completely unleash on hordes of poor baddies.  The story's neat, and the time travel schtick allows for a couple of great keystone moments.

It feels like a lighter Metro game, which is all good in my book.  Grab it!

34844620.review:
Also dann, Singularity.
Das Ist ein Titel der irgendwie völlig untergegangen ist. Keine Ahnung wieso. 
Man spielt mehr oder weneiger einen Zeitreisenden, der unbeabsichtigt die Geschichte verändert und dann versucht diese in Ordnung zu bringe. Dabei hüpft man, wohlgemerkt an festen Punkten im Spiel, zwischen der Gegenwart und dem Jahr 1955 hin und her um alles wieder ins Lot zu bringen.
Neben diversen Schießeisen stellt das kleine Gerät, welches die Zeitsprünge ermöglicht, das wichtigste Werkzeug dabei dar. Es ermöglicht kleinere Spielereien, wie Objekte bewegen, in einem kleineren Umkreis die Zeit einzufrieren oder bestimmte Objekte, ja sogar Gegner, in Sekunden altern zu lassen. Diese Mechaniken werden auch für kleine Rätseleinlagen benutzt. Diese sind dabei sehr spärlich, wirken auch nicht all zu sehr aufgesetzt (wie das Wippenrätsel in Halb-Lebens Geschichte 2) und fügen sich somit ein. 
Der Shooter Part macht Spaß. wobei ich finde, das die Waffen sich irgendwie nicht so dolle anhören. 

Eine weitere Mechanik ist die möglichkeit des Aufrüstens von Waffen, der Figur (Lebensenergie, mitführbare Medikits...) und des Zeitmaschienchens (Energiereserven, Dauer des Zeiteinfrierens...). Upgrade Mechaniken sind ja überall dabei. Was mich hieran nur stört, ist die verfügbarkeit von Upgradstationen im Spiel. Irgendjemand hat die netter weise wohl so gut wie überall aufgestellt. Ich frage mich da wirklich, was sich dieser jemand dachte. "Hm, diesem Treppenhaus fehlt etwas...Ah ja! Natürlich! eine Waffenupgrade-Station!"

Von technischer Seite her kommt mir in erster Linie das Sichtfeld zu schmälern vor. Anfangs wirkt alles etwas rangezoomt, einen Regler zum ändern gibt es nicht. Man gewöhnt sich aber daran.
Katastrophal dagegen ist ein mega Problem der verwendeten Engine: Das Texturen streaming. Das funktioniert gar nicht. Zu häufig wurden Texturen bei mir nicht geladen oder nur viel zu langsam. Dabei gab es noch nicht mal das all seits beliebte Texturen-plopp-in, für das die Unreal Engine ja so beliebt ist. Nein, hier ist es wirklich so, das ganze Wände, Figuren und Co einfarbig bleiben. Und erst drei Minuten später die volle Textur spendiert bekommen. Das Optionsmenü gibt keine Einstellmöglichkeiten her um das zu korrigieren.
Und ja, das macht wahnsinnig die Atmosphäre kaputt, wenn alles wie aus einem Bilder-aufklapp-Buch aussieht.

In den Multiplayer habe ich nicht reingesehen. Was auch mega schwer ist, da keiner den derzeit spielt. Und es werden auch noch sechs Personen benötigt um eine Zufalls Partie zu starten. Also viel Glück.

Alles in allem fand ich mich gut unterhalten, auch wenn das Spiel so verdammt kurz ist. Spielt man lange und sieht sich oft um, braucht man vielleicht zwei Abende. Oder man hat keinerlei Pflichten und sonstiges zu tun, dann geht es auch an einem. Ich habe ungefähr sechs Stunden Spielzeit gebraucht, einmal das Ende zu erreichen.
Die Endings, ja es gibt hier mehrere, sind dabei wirklich gut gelungen. Ich finde die zwei von drei die ich bislang gesehen habe, wirklich passend. 

Raven Software hat hiermit wieder einmal einen netten, wenn auch kurzen, Shooter abgeliefert, der eigene Mechaniken und seinen eigenen Stil aufweist und damit zu Gefallen weiß.

Für kleines Geld in jedem Sale für Shooter Freunde zu empfehlen!

34785822.review:
[h1] O Viajante do Tempo sem rumo [/h1]

  Singularity é um jogo de tiro em primeira pessoa(FPS), onde jogamos como o soldado americano Nathaniel [b] Renko [/b] em uma missão de chegar numa ilha de domínio soviético conhecida como Katorga-12., no ano de 2010. Contudo, o helicóptero que o protagonista está é abatido e cai na ilha. A partir disso, o jogo realmente começa.

  Há um dispositivo, conhecido como DMT(Dispositivo de Manipulação Temporal), em português. [b] Renko [/b], de alguma forma, consegue voltar no tempo, e muda o curso da história. Dessa maneira, é necessário fazer de tudo para reverter a mudança. Para tal, contamos com a ajuda de Barisov, o soviético criador do dispositivo, e Kathryn, membro da MIR-12, uma organização secreta de resistência.
 
  A história é linear, mesmo sobre viagens no tempo. Por outro lado, há 3 finais diferentes. Uma boa sacada dos desenvolvedores é que, ao finalizar o jogo e escolher um final, o jogo retorna para o capítulo final, onde você pode escolher um novo final.


PROS:
- História muito interessante
- Poderes legais
- Gráficos bons para a época(2010)
- Gameplay simples e interessante
- Múltiplos finais(exatamente 3)


CONS:
- Curta duração da campanha
- Sem legendas(nem em inglês)




FINAL: se souber inglês e tiver dinheiro sobrando, é um jogo excelente.
NOTA: 9/10

34605807.review:
This is a great little FPS with a decent, pulpy time travel plot that has more to do than just shoot stuff. There are a couple fun guns and there are some environmental puzzles to help break up the shooting monotony. I'm not much for full-on shooters. I prefer games with some puzzles and exploring like Tomb Raider.

This reminds me a bit of a B-grade Half-Life 2. It is fairly short and linear, but pretty fun and quite clever occasionally. It rarely goes on sale and I don't know if most people would like it for the asking price, but it ended up being a couple dollars per hour and I thought that was worth it. Light, but entertaining.

People who liked Quantum Break might like this. It also has some creepy parts and reminded me a bit of Condemned: Criminal Origins and maybe the Metro series a bit.

Pas mauvais en soit, mais très décevant.

Ici, la manipulation du temps, sensé être l'originalité de ce jeu, n'est utilisé que de façon anecdotique. Une énigme par ci, un remplacement d'un shotgun par là...

34358483.review: It has been years since this released. It's one of the last disc games I owned. I had misplaced the disc and saw it on sale so I bought it on a whim. I ran through it again on the hardest difficulty and played a few mp matches and it holds up extremely well. In fact I'd say its one of the top 50 shooters out there. I know that the development was troubled and so the game got bad press because it fell short of expectations of both the developer and the press. If this game hadn't been given an eleven month deadline for completion it might have been the best shooter ever. As it is, it is awesome and truly enjoyable all the way through. The things you can do with the temporal powers in combat aren't explained very well but when you discover them they are the best I've seen in a game still. You can routinely get it on sale for a 1.49. That might be the best deal on steam. If you have a few friends you can convince to look under their couch cushions for change to buy it, the multiplayer is a blast. Its pretty amazing how fun the multiplayer actually is.

Zamanında playstation üzerinden oynamıştım şimdi arşivimde bulunması için indirimde iken almış bulunmaktayım. Farklı bir bilim kurgu deneyimi yaşamak isteyenlere tavsiyemdir.

34155060.review: Not bad at all for $6. What you'd expect from a few years back. Decent story if you've got the patience to pore through journal entries. Some enemies seem a bit immune to the more powerful weapons you collect which can be a bit frustrating. Overall, good story, decent gameplay, and good for a quick run-through. Fans of Timeshift should definitely try it.

34105970.review: Singularity combines first-person shooting and time device manipulation in a great way. You can shoot enemies to death, or expend energy to kill them using time itself (advancing or reversing it). Not only is this usable in combat, but you can also reverse time to fix broken stuff like machines or stairways, and age obstacles to the point of degradation so you can get past them. The gameplay is fun, and the story is surprisingly good for a first person shooter a lot of people haven't heard about. It's no BioShock, of course, but it's got a good plot for an action-heavy shooter, including multiple endings. I've beaten the game once on PC and once on PS3. It's a good game.

34102194.review:
Really fun horror FPS game that was, as I learned only after finishing it, made by Raven Software whom one might know from titles such as Heretic, Hexen and Soldier of Fortune.
It's set on a Soviet research facility dealing with a mysterious newly found source of energy. Things go wrong, you know it goes. The story is not anything special, but it helps to paint a pleasant spooky atmosphere along with audio logs and some memos scattered around. 
The game is nicely paced and varies things a bit between shooting soldiers and various mutants. You'll have a Time Manipulation Device to help you through this, giving you various superpowers related to time and reverting objects and enemies. There's of course the standard FPS arsenal of weapons, of which I'll mention a rifle with a bulletcam you can steer and also a steerable grenade launcher. Weapons feel fine to shoot and you can upgrade them with doodads you find along the way. 
I don't remember any big hype about this game and it seems it was just not very popular, which is a shame because I really liked it. Only dated thing was some textures that were quite low quality, even for 2010.

34098020.review:
Singularity или Клюквенный Коктейль От Raven С Примесью Трэша

Освежая недавно в памяти Call Of Duty Black Ops меня посетила мысль, что пожалуй не стоит переигрывать в игры которые тебе нравились ощутимое время назад (http://store.steampowered.com/recommended/recommendgame/42700). Я рискнул, и опять прогадал. Но начнем по порядку. Компании Raven ИМХО чего-то постоянно не хватает, что бы выпускаемый ей продукт получился "как нужно". Так было с Quake 4, Wolfenstein 2009, Call Of Duty Ghosts (cовсем древние релизы я не рассматриваю, равно как и звездные войны и прочие гомиксы). Так случилось и с Singularity. Прошу выше и ниже сказанное рассматривать как ИМХО - возможно Ваше мнение будет кардинально отличаться от Моего.

И так, мы имеем дело с фантастическим шутером от первого лица в своебразном сеттинге и довольно интересными фишками, жаль только что реализовано это все не так как хотелось бы... А был бы понтенциальный хит...  В кратце о сюжете. Главный герой с группой демократических товарищей высаживается на отдаленном острове, на котором ученые СССР проводили эксперименты с новым химическим элементом. Слувшийся взрыв затянул главного героя в прошлое, где он, по незнанию спас главного противника, изменив тем самым прошлое-настоящее-будущее. Нам же предстоит теперь вернуть все как было...Спойлерить не буду - кто заинтересуется - please welcome, игра не так дорого стоит (удивительно для Activision не правда ли?)

Игра была бы лучше если б (читай минусы, которых не так мало кстати:)
-Графоний. Для 2010 года - слабЕнько, а сейчас и подавно
-Палитра цветов - совершенно не понравилась
-Модели - слабо
-Дизайн уровней - сказывается какая-то недоделанность и кустарщина
-Боевка - так же не сильная сторона (оружие и произвоимый им эффект совсем не понравились, равно как и его количество в игре)
-Дисбаланс по прокачке - если примерно на 70% игры я уже выкачал все доступные умения, то прокачка оружия еще могла и быть использована
-Отсутсвие карточек и достижений
-Отсутсвие русского языка
-Клюква (БАрисов, Каторга, Мир), Такое чувство, что запад нашу страну представляет так, как им вдолбили в головы в 50-60х годах
-Вооружение и обмундирование отличное от реально сущесвовавшего в 1950-х годах
-Неудачная раскладка по умолчанию - подобрать/взаимодействовать и перезарядка -одна кнопка

ну и плюсы (то что не сумели испортить)
-Нелинейная концовка
-(В принципе, если закрыть кое-на что глаза) неплохой сюжет
-Прокачка оружия и способностей

33754062.review:
tl;dr buy it on a steep discount (no more than $10) or skip it. Campaign is too short and the innovative components of the game are not as fleshed out as they could be

**A game that tries to do too much with too little.**

It tries to be Bioshock with its mixture of "magical" combat and "conventional" combat--but neither one of them is exceptionally interesting unless the individual items are progressed through leveling them up.

It tries to implement item progression for both the "magical" and "conventional" weapons through a currency found through "exploration"--but the maps are extremely linear and don't provide any real rewards for finding the items that allow you to level up the items.

The weapon progression doesn't seem to help a lick with your capabilities in the game. As soon you have enough time to level up particular weapons--the enemies get harder. This makes the unupgraded items worse and puts the upgraded items back at square one. This removes a good deal of player choice in loadout.

What I do like though: When you are actually in a circumstance where a particular weapon would be situationally useful--the game actually straight up gives them to you. "Oh, boss fight. Here is a weapon locker that allows you to swap out." "Oh, an open field? Here is a sniper right and a minigun. Pick one" I appreciate that immensely.

But back to upgrading. The progressive upgrades themselves are not very differentiated: Magazine size, reload speed, and damage. With no clear indicator of *how much* those stats are improved--its impossible to make an informed opinion. Not that it will matter any way because the vaguely scaling enemy difficulty will render your upgrades pointless anyway.

And then towards the end of the game--an entire line of upgrades is completely obsoleted by the removal of particular limitations on a specific item.

There is decent variety in enemies but some of the enemies are either obnoxious to deal with (ticks) or are boring to fight against (normal human soldiers). What unique and creative enemies they *do* have are easily mitigated by certain skills and become rote to defeat.

The boss battles--and I use that term lightly--are uninspired and boring. Once you figure out the mechanic of the boss, its a rinse-and-repeat affair.

And the ending(s). I'm not going to say much but lets just say "multiple endings" is a little disingenuious.

The most annoying part, though? The game also plays ridiculously fast. I beat it on hard in four hours. HLTB claimed a completion time of 7.5 so your mileage may vary. I would only consider buying this if it was very cheap. I cannot believe the publisher is trying to get someone to pay $30 for a game published in 2010!
